@dudleyjoshua @DescriptApp @audiographio I'm not shitting on Descript as a solution, I'm just Cranky Kong-ing it up on my timeline because they're suggesting audio engineering is reducible to a non-complicated endeavor. https://t.co/BjQaOcmu2W

@dudleyjoshua @DescriptApp I don't know about that. I mean, like I said in the thread, I do use it to transcribe before post-production work starts in earnest, but there are plenty of free products out there that give you time-stamped transcripts... like @audiographio.
@plasticAudio @DescriptApp Yeah, I don't disagree. It's disrespectful as hell. It's like saying "You can be a doctor if you buy this $100 first aid kit from DrDad(dot)com."

Audio Engineering is 👏 a 👏 high 👏 skill 👏 job 👏

Stop talking about your one-button products like they are as good as an audio engineer.

Those products are cheaper, they're maybe more efficient, but they aren't as good as a skilled audio engineer who knows their shit.

@plasticAudio @DescriptApp To be fair, they do clarify later in the article that eventually "good enough" (not knowing what you're doing and just throwing some one-button solves at the audio)  isn't good enough anymore and you really need to learn what you're doing... but you wouldn't do that in Descript. https://t.co/wqnXlsILOR
I mean, no one is mastering an album on Descript. lol

Descript isn't a tool for professionals, though it might augment toolkits. Example, I've trained clients to say a key phrase when the do a retake, so I'll use Descript to transcribe the episode pre-post to find the retake points, drag those timestamps into Studio One...

.@DescriptApp not to be an asshole but if people were thinking like audio engineers, they wouldn't be engineering in Descript. Eventually good enough isn't good enough, as you say; that means eventually you graduate from Descript. https://t.co/wswbQGrVH0 #PodNation #IndiePodcast

@LeoJAllenJr But maybe it’s just a weekly show, that’s 30k per ep * 4.3 weeks in a month = 129,000. Stick one $30CPM ad in that and you’re looking at $3800/mo in revenue. We’re building revenue verticals, that’s the point.

@LeoJAllenJr Imagine you spend $20k growing a daily podcast to a listenership of only 30,000. Let’s say it takes you 8-months. 30k a day 23 episodes a month… that’s 690k downloads a month. Stick one 60 second ad on that show with a $30CPM and you’ve got $20k/mo in revenue.
@LeoJAllenJr Oh 100% I don’t sell to indies - it’s unjustifiable. I work with people who want to grow an audience of 50,000 and understand that might cost $10k-$20k. But here’s the thing…

@LeoJAllenJr I charge $1800-$2000 a month plus ad spend. Usually the ad spend is $1000-$1500. So that’s $3500 at the top. Anyone charging $5k without ad spend… I mean I don’t know their efficacy but that’s a lot.

Some of the higher level stuff I'm doing to grow my podcast:

1. Huge SEO focus (structured data and schema)

2. Having a Wikipedia page authored

3. Writing blogs near-daily (pairs with #1)

4. Going after numerous larger media opportunities (mostly in print).
From a @podcastingsucks YouTube channel which of these would you want MOST? #IndiePodcast #PodNation
Thread on Feed Drops! https://t.co/EU6ESlnORT

And one last thing, I respect what Lindsay has achieved in what is truly a short amount of time, he knows his shit and he produces great content - there's no debating that - this isn't about Lindsay's prowess as a creator, it's about keeping the rest of you realistic.

So feeddrops? Sure, go for it, but that shouldn't be even a primary strategy for most of you. Most of you should be writing more, looking for local PR opportunities more, courting media relationships more, and doing all the other things the Lindsay did to get to where he is today

You, regular 'ol indie podcasters with far less than 1000 unique listeners, do not have the organic juice that Lindsay has accumulated over 4-years of working hard to produce top tier content and then being recognized over time for it, regularly, for it.

"All the rest of it" being, exactly all the things Lindsay has done. A great website, great content, multiple PR opportunities in print and television, having a meaningful budget, being assisted by Wondery... feeddrops are not responsible for Lindsay's success.

I would never suggest a podcaster not consider appearing in front of a prequalified audience - that would be insane - but I do like to remind people that if you're appearing in front of very tiny qualified audiences, feed drops are not going to do more than *all the rest of it*

When Lindsay Graham does a feed-drop, he's likely doing it on podcasts with significant listenerships and conversions on feeddrops are a semi-fixed percentage, the larger the audience (and the more qualified) the more conversions. Your feeddrop on a 75 listener podcast nets +1.
The podcast is popular enough to have its own wikipage, for goodness sake. https://t.co/auS2M0MhaH

It does suggest there's a lot more going on here that feed drops. Lindsay has been creating this podcast for over four years. Part of his success, then, must needs be driven by an accumulated body of indexable work. Look at these results: https://t.co/BopQve7i00

Lindsay Graham is not a normative podcaster. The podcasts he feed drops on, the backing he has, the exposure he receives in the press, his appearances on television, all of it, is non-normative among independent podcasters. This doesn't invalidate his experience, but...

I want to clearly express why this advice should be considered but not relied upon as broadly good advice. Read Lindsay's entire thread first, it has great data in it, then come back and read this one. https://t.co/xdwaQxzrP6

For me, that's: 

- Episodes every Monday through Friday
- 1-3 blog posts per week
- 90% social activity on Twitter 10% on Instagram

For you it might be:

- Episodes every Tuesday
- 1 blog post per week
- 100% social activity on Instagram

Just be doing it.

@CrimeTrialsPod @ListenNotes @audiochuck 1. Chartable is accurate, whether that information is useful, it is at least objectively true.

2. Goodpods numbers are relative to the Goodpods platform - which is unique in that most users are podcasters themselves.

Before you start using paid social (which I'm a huge advocate of) make sure you're doing all the following:

1. Releasing episodes consistently and reliably
2. Blogging around your niche at least weekly
3. Engaging on your preferred social platform(s)

Those things are basics.

And if you can't do that, you don't then make, in this example, traditional burial illegal and fine or imprison those who do it, you simply accept that some people won't be on board and you must, in a civilized and liberal society, accept that. You can't force the world to be X.

And the more controversial your idea, the more important this becomes. You cannot just get mad that people don't see it your way, you have to work to discover why they don't. You can't dismiss them out of hand as fools or idiots, you have to help them understand.

Me: "Then doesn't that mean you need to convince people who don't already thinks it's a good idea?"

Them: "..."

Me: "Then you've got to be more careful with how you word the thing you're talking about."

To which they replied, "People already want to do this, and they're comfortable with the language."

To which I replied, "Isn't this about making the world a greener place?"

Them: "Yes."

They asked why, and I said "Because for something that private, personal, and human, you cannot suggest that what you're doing to Grandma is the same thing you do to your old orange and banana peels. It's insensitive and undignified."

The motivation for the concept is greener disposal of human remains. And, less expensive disposal of human remains. It's a "Green effort" according to this person.

They want to refer to the process in their literature as "composting" and I told them they shouldn't.

Here's a non topical example: a friend of mine wants to start a human body composting operation (which is something you can do in Colorado).

The idea is that you'll be composted and your remains will be given to your loved ones to use as they see fit. Maybe plant a garden with.

There's what is true.

There's what is false.

Then there is what people think.

You can't scream the truth, or the lie, and believe that's all that matters.

You have to win hearts and minds. 

If you're not willing to do that, your truth (or your lie) will not prevail. https://t.co/J69XHeu2as

The CDC makes a lot of educated guesses, and they are *educated* guesses, but they've been wrong A LOT with those guesses (as we seem to find out a few months later) and that's enough of a reason for people to be skeptical. Voiceing that skepticism isn't deserving of censorship.

And saying it's pageantry isn't spreading false information it's providing a genuine criticism. Same with these t-shirt material masks. We've got people running around in bedazzled cloths masks lecturing anti-maskers on the importance of masks when cloth masks don't do much.

I mean, think about where we are on this Covid thing. I ate in a restaurant last night with a maximum occupancy of 50 people, it was small. I had to wear a mask from the door to my seat, less than 20-ft, and then, for 2-hours I sat there with a mask off. That's pageantry.

But @joerogan is having a single individual onto his show and he's giving him a platform to criticize COVID narratives based on that guest's professional and anecdotal experience. Does a Doctor not have the right to dissent on a podcast?

What @joerogan is doing is allowing people to present the "COVID narrative" in a critical and frequently negative light. But that's not the same as "spreading misinformation"... spreading misinformation is more like organized propaganda, like what our news outlets do.

One of the reasons the @joerogan / @Spotify / @Neilyoung thing sits so awkwardly with me is because it's a very BIG example of something I think we're beginning to get more and more wrong as Americans. We're favoring tyrannical approaches to problem solving over diplomatic ones.

While I can't trust data provided by podcast hosting providers, I know I can at least trust the data provided by Spotify since they can link listens to a user account reliably and without inflating my numbers. #PodNation #IndiePodcast #IndiePodcastsUnite #RSSCantDoThat https://t.co/pLt5iVSHOW
@williamchernoff I wouldn't think very much so. They're able to combine more individual data points to identify a single person. User account, of course, being the big one.
And I'm not blaming anyone for that, I think it's just another problem with being limited to RSS distribution in this medium.

I think, in reality, I have 250-(250*.30)=175 regular listeners and privacy technology, IPv6 addresses (because they're dynamic), and other unknowns are conspiring to drastically inflate the Unique Listener value for all of us. https://t.co/hzO2yerxqp

Example of why I don't trust it. My monthly unique is over 1000. My daily average after 30-days? ~250 downloads per episode. You're telling me I'm attracting ~750 first time, one-time, listeners a month? No way. I don't buy it.

There's a part of @iab standards for podcast measurement that I don't trust: Unique Listeners. I still think you should take your 30-day per-episode average and reduce it by 30% to get an accurate reading on how many regular listeners you actually have. (1 of 2)

I must be lazy. I must need to muscle up." but there are many things for which that approach does not, cannot work.

@KingJosh_____ @blue_leadership @Linda_McMahon @ZetaCompaore @TomBilyeu @GaryLineker @OpieRadio @SMExaminer @randomguy495 @SugaSeanMMA Barring a physiological or chemical issue, a person suddenly feeling underwhelmed by their workouts could increase their intensity or, if that didn't work, that person should consider what else might be going on. Depression, a drop in testosterone as you age, a dietary change.

@KingJosh_____ @blue_leadership @Linda_McMahon @ZetaCompaore @TomBilyeu @GaryLineker @OpieRadio @SMExaminer @randomguy495 @SugaSeanMMA Or, potentially, speaking of neurotransmitters, one could have a deficiency requiring medical intervention. I, for example, produce significantly less dopamine than the average person. No amount of working out or discipline could make me produce more. It's a physical defect.

@jlillyproject @TeachCultCast Okay, I agree with that mostly. It’s proof you made something and now another creator can’t ripoff you creations. That’s good 👍
@jlillyproject @TeachCultCast All that’s fine, just another way to buy sell trade and distribute, I just don’t see any intrinsic benefit for creators… beyond more ways to divide their efforts. 🤷‍♂️

@jlillyproject @TeachCultCast Marketing is identifying, targeting, then reaching, those who you've identified as potentially interested. On social there are things in place which allow a savvy person to do this... what's the analogue for an advertising platform in Web3?

@jlillyproject @TeachCultCast Another gold rush, more scrambling for attention early on... then right back to where we're already at: too much noise, to many places, and still no solves for marketing and promotion. I would think fewer since those engines can't be built across a decentralized landscape.

@jlillyproject @TeachCultCast More new venues doesn't = easier marketing it just means additional distribution endpoints. And yes, you're right, there's an uncapped organic reach benefit when it's new... but how about when it isn't? Seems like a gain only for early adopters then we're right back to how it is.
Check this out yourself, and I wouldn't mind a few love letter myself! If you don't mind 😘 https://t.co/kpTnmYhaKn

@jlillyproject @TeachCultCast Because in my eyes, added distribution channels doesn't aide in discoverability, only findability... a subtle but critical difference that I've had unfortunately little luck helping people to understand.
@jlillyproject @TeachCultCast Explain how it will be easier to market oneself.
Again, I know nothing about web3/blockchain, but these are my concerns as someone who isn't in the thick of it. Help me understand how I'm wrong if you feel I am. It would be better to be smarter!

It's hard enough to market and grow on a centralized internet where we have the benefit of algorithms and discoverability engines (when we have them), but web3 seems like it puts everyone on "me island" and why would anyone go there? And how would they get a map to it?

In follow-up to my latest episode, where @TeachCultCast asks me about Web3 (something I'm not at all knowledgeable about): I'm sure Web 3 will give us many new ways to create, but I feel it will make it harder to grow because it will be harder to market ourselves.

If your answer is "yes"... I would ask you to reflect a little bit. Why do you feel a person's station in life should determine their health, safety, and comfort if they're putting in as many hours as you are.

If your answer to that is "no", then your problem isn't with what you think it's with. You're probably upset that a grocery bagger makes as much as a paramedic - and there, I'm with you - but that's a different problem with a different root cause.

And the argument doesn't even need to be about quality of life, or family planning, or personal responsibility, that just drags all of us into the mud for a never ending fight over details.

The only question is this: 

Should a person working 40-hours a week live in poverty?
Federal minimum wage is $7.25. At 40-hours a week and in the 15% tax bracket, that's $246.50 a week. There are 4.3 weeks in a month... that's $1059.95 per month, net. That's $12,818 per year.

For those who might say "$15/hr is too much to bag groceries" I would tell you that I don't, on premise, disagree with you. But it's also not the point, the point is the cost of living doesn't match minimum wage and that must be corrected.

My family history (Alcoa Aluminum, early to mid 1900s) would suggest I'd be anti-union... and in some ways I suppose I am, but I'm not against the concept of workers needing collective bargaining power. People deserve a voice equal to industry, if not greater, this is America.

So, tomorrow some #union workers at #KingSoopers locations in Denver (that's one of our grocery store chains - it's owned by @kroger) will strike to receive the state minimum wage of $15 (currently they receive the Denver minimum wage of ~$12.56).

Best of luck to them ✊

Creators want reach, they want realistic, attainable, and repeatable monetization success, and they need fewer moving parts because they're working too hard for marginal numbers. This writing has been on the wall for almost 5-years. Change is inevitable, closed is the future.

For years the industry has refused to change, refused to adapt to the demands of its creators, and has refused to give creators what they need. All the while, spinning up products on rotting scaffolding, making money, while telling creators they had to support "the current model"

The beginning shows the mountains they cross, the birch trees Maria walks between (gravestones), she flees them to a stream where she carefully times her jump, and then she’s back to the safety of the open hillside.

Think about how SoM ends. They cross the mountains to flee Austria into Switzerland. Before that they flee the Convent. Before that they hide behind grave stones. Before that they carefully time their escape from the festival.

Hold up. Is the first part of the Sound of Music the exact opposite of the final act?

This is blowing my mind.

@drivinintoday Part of it is meeting podcasters where they are and doing so as a podcast host. And to present content to them that is podcast, not marketing, content. But that’s both easy and obvious. The hard part is getting in front of someone likely to enjoy your podcast in the first place.

If you're selling a podcast, get your podcast in front of them in the form of a podcast... not an audiogram, not a blog post, not a gif, not a meme - a podcast. 

That other shit is to keep your *current* audience engaged, and you at the top of their minds.

Using repurposed content to recruit new listenership is like trying to sell beer to new customers by giving them bottles of water with your beers label on them.

It's a disconnect between what they choose to engage in and the form of the desired engagement. 

This is 101.

Repurposed content is best used to maintain listenership. You shouldn't be using it to attract new listeners. Why? Because if your repurposed audio, in the form of a blog, resonates with someone, it is because they are looking for a blog. What does that have to do with a podcast?

@indiedropin @podcast_father And by that I mean if an ad buyer distributes a $10K budget across 100 podcasts, they get theirs no matter what... but the individual podcaster just gets their mediocre share in the form of CPM rates. And that's fucking nothing if you're 60% of podcasts out there.

@indiedropin @podcast_father 100%. It's what I get most riled up about because the industry is like "use this method" and the industry is like "dope, we get the collective benefit of all of you" but the creator only gets their singular slice of that benefit.

@podcast_father @indiedropin If you want your podcast to be a full-time income on traditional monetization methods alone, you need about 30,000 subscribers with both ads and a patreon/supercast type option. That will bring you to the $50K/yr mark just barely.

@podcast_father @indiedropin They don't understand that it's GOING to be a full-time job no matter how you do it.

You can monetize through courses, through ads, through services, etc, but you're creating a 40-hour a week (or 80-hour, heh) job for yourself... and if that's not what you want, it's a prison.

@podcast_father @indiedropin Too labor intensive for me, personally. I'd spend 3-hours a day on pre-sale calls, and 4-hours a week in live tutoring sessions. I was always selling or always teaching, and it took me a way from consultation work and from... let's call it pro-bono teaching in the community...

@podcast_father @indiedropin Like a course, with a live element to it, then you can convert some of that audience.

I had 34 students graduate that course. 22 of them still generate between $3K and $7K a month in gross earnings using this method. I no longer teach this course because it's too labor intensive

@podcast_father @indiedropin That need could be information, it could be escapism, it could be how-to or inspirational in nature, whatever it is, they trust you to give it to them. 

If you could expand on what you're providing and provide more of it in a less restrictive and more personal medium...

@podcast_father @indiedropin I used to teach a course on course creation (which sounds obnoxiously pyramidical, I know) but the concept was essentially this:

People listen to your podcast because they A.) like you, B.) see you as a resource for something they need.

@podcast_father @indiedropin My podcasting business is more of an audio business. I currently earn around $200K gross and net somewhere in the $130K ballpark after costs of doing business. 23% of that is the direct result of my podcast so... my podcast earns me ~$30K/yr NET. I don't view that as FT.

Hope I'm wrong but, of course, I don't think I am. 

If I were an indie podcaster concerned with the future, I'd be adding video to my production - and I'd be doing it quickly.

I also think it will further hurt indies who can't afford to meet this new expectation of consumers the way those with big budgets and production teams can... which will further reduce the content diversity in the medium because even fewer shows will get any attention.

Video when you can watch, audio when you cannot. Move from the car to the house, stream video to the tv. Move from the couch to the car, pick up the audio where you disconnected from the television. I think this will become the standard expectation.

As we see the "yes" response grow, I believe we are ignoring this proliferation in delivery forms and consumption habits. I believe audio will take a backseat to video by 2023. @spotifypodcasts has prepared well for this, creating the ability to seemlessly switch between the two.

We've seen affirmative responses to the question "Do you listen to podcasts" increase steadily over the years, but when it is asked, what are the respondents imagining? An audio only production? A livestream that calls itself a podcast? A Streamyard recording on LinkedIn?

From this morning's episode of @podcastingsucks 

The public's understanding of what a podcast is, is changing consumer expectations of what a podcast should be, and that is what will most drive the coming changes to our medium.

If the deposit covers the cost, you don't pay. Or if it's less, you get some of that money back. But if it's more, you pay more at the time of return... not before. Not in advance. I've rented from Avis, Hertz, Thrifty, and even Enterprise and I've never pre-paid. Ever.

Usually the process is you give an estimated date of return, you pay a deposit with a credit card, and you bring it back when you bring it back. Usually within a day or two of when you said you'd bring it back. When you return it, you pay.

@JonathanJSpeaks High school teaches you nothing about being a human being, with the exception, maybe, of how to successfully navigate a cultural hierarchy. That's not useless, of course, but most of the rest of it is.

@ProjectDave21 Dude I went to school for Philosophy. PHILOSOPHY. I could have learned all that shit for free at the library on the weekends while I had a job digging ditches for minimum wage and I'd of left my parent's home with a way to really move forward in life. Whoops.

So spend your twenties seriously committed to being frugal, hard-working, and unconcerned with socializing. Your thirties will thank you for it. 

You know, or go to college and have to sell your reproductive bits to pay off your debt while you still can't find a job. Whatever.

Do y'all know how long people live? I'm 38 and I'm looking at another 40-50 years of life (you know, providence willing). I've worked since I was 14... that's only 24-years. I've got that many working years left until retirement. We have SO MUCH TIME.

Keep at it for another four years, you'll be 25, and you'll have properly established yourself in your industry. And guess what? If you chose the wrong job (like you'd chose the wrong major maybe) you're only fucking 25 - AND you've got income. You can try something else safely.

Pick something you think you like, get an internship for a year, work hard, transition to employee, live at home til you're 21, and in the same amount of time you'd of spent at college, you'll be making enough money to rent a small place on your own.

Get an internship at 18, get hired at 19, work for 3-years, and in 9 our of 10 cases you'll know enough about whatever industry you got into to move into specialization, or middle-management. And you won't have insane levels of debt. I mean, holy shit. This story is depressing.

And that was, "have a yard sale" not a "hard sale"... @TwitterBlue, please roll out tweet edits soon. Please?

And when I say "No one is waiting with bated breath..." I mean just that. YOU are creating false urgency, no one else knows you're planning anything... you're creating an expectation of *yourself* and rushing to meet it for... who? Slow down. Save some money, start better.

🧵If you're in the #PodernFamily or #IndiePodcast or #PodNation families, and you're just about to start a podcast, but you haven't pulled the trigger yet, and you're thinking about using your phone to "just start" - PLEASE, read this thread. https://t.co/sOdAF0vZqa

Don't "just start", no one is waiting with bated breath for you to launch your podcast... or, rather, DO "just start" but consider *saving money* part of the starting process. You need to stand a chance out here, and your phone-recorded podcast isn't a great breakout strategy.

If you're a podcaster with in person guests or an in-person cohost, (or an in-person co-host and remote guests) it's a pricier investment, but it's still worth it. Get a Zoom Podtrak P4 ($199) and the @AudioTechnicaUK AT2040 ($99).

If you're a solocaster, or a podcaster with only remote co-hosts or guests, get at least a USB mic. Something like the @AudioTechnicaUK ATR2100X-USB, it's $80. Can't afford it? Have a hard sale. This is a worthwhile investment if your only other option is the phone.

Are they going to stick around?

Maybe. Maybe if your content is just THAT good, and if the chemistry with your co-host is infectious, and you're just top tier from word one.

But most probably? No. They'll disappear faster than a toupee on a windy day.

That means what they're becoming used to is decent audio recorded on decent equipment.

Now they find your podcast, through some Christmas miracle they happen across your podcast, and they hit play... they hear you recording it in your living room on your iPhone - no edits.

Top 200 podcasts are top 200 because they're popular, never mind why they're popular, that doesn't matter, but they ARE popular, so the chances that when people answer the question "do you listen to podcasts?" in the affirmative that they listen to podcasts in the top 200 is good

If you're listening to Ghostwriter, On Purpose with Jay Shetty, The Breakfast Club, and The Daily Stoic (examples from the top 200) you're listening to podcasts that are recorded in decent environments and on decent equipment and which have decent to excellent editing/engineering

Podcast listeners may not think of themselves as discerning but if you look at the Top 200 podcasts in Apple Podcasts, they clearly are - even if they've only been trained to be without knowing it was happening.

Y'all listen. You can start a podcast with your phone... it's a fine way to experiment, to figure out if the medium of podcasting scratches whatever itch you've got, but, long-term? You just shouldn't. I'm going to tell you why in this mini-thread.

@ProjectDave21 There will be a pro version at $99/year to attend monthly live classes and there will be a way too book 1:1 time with me, but all the instruction, and I mean complete instructions, not like half measures so you buy the full version, will be 100% free.

Save your money. You don’t need a $5000 course on Facebook Ads, or SEO, that stuff exists for free, right now. You just need it organized. The app I’m working to release before the year is out will do exactly this, and it will do it for free. As in $0, no charge. Just hold off.

All these marketing gurus that are offering high ticket courses to grow your Instagram, your authority, or whatever, are employing methods that were new a decade ago… now they’re mainstream enough that 20 and 30-somethings are teaching masterminds in them.

The thing about marketing tactics (of any kind) is that as soon as you see everyone teaching them, and everyone doing them, it’s likely that they don’t work anymore. Once the bleeding edge is the standard strategy, there’s no longer any advantage in it. #PodNation #IndiePodcast

@arithisandthat @BryanBarletta @CaptivateAudio It's probably a better, and I would say more practical approach, to tell podcasters to normalize their loudness to -15LUFS, and simply wait until podcasting platforms do what they already do to fully mastered music. When that happens, if you're +/- 1LU, you'll be fine.

@arithisandthat @BryanBarletta If @CaptivateAudio's new AMIE system (for example) were to do this for the podcaster, they'd need, and this is just an example: a -16LUFS file for Apple Podcasts, and a -14LUFS file for Spotify... they'd need to either host two different fils or normalize it as it went out.

@arithisandthat @BryanBarletta The responsibility to "enforce" this could fall to the hosting provider but that might be a challenge since, in both streaming music and (I imagine) any would be standard in podcasting, each platform has a different expectation. So the host would need multiple versions.

@arithisandthat @BryanBarletta It's loudness normalization, sometimes people (incorrectly) say, "I mastered it to -X LUFS." The solution is a cross platform standard, and then the enforcement of that standard. Currently, in music, when a song does not meet this standard, the platform modifies the file.

Structuring your podcast as a business graduates you from this very loose, chaotic approach to action and forces you to get focused and, like I said, become more intentional. It is the difference between wide-eyed wandering and purposeful journeying. https://t.co/PNAFwtYcbp

The saying "Money is the root of all evil" is misquoted.

The quote is "For THE LOVE of money is the root of all evil."

If you use money as a tool to reach your goals (again, however you define those), you do not love money, you love the goal.

By structuring our podcasts as businesses, by creating a budget and considering money (the spending and earning of it) we force ourselves to adopt a different way of thinking about our decisions. We become more intentional. We don't lose the whimsy, we gain a kind of discipline.

You have a goal. It might be money (a full-time living, perhaps), or it might be impact, reach, education, or something else. The point is, those goals require strategy, they require a different kind of thinking than the "artist thinking" we're prone too.

Hey #PodNation and #IndiePodcast you may not be ready to see it but you're running a business. You might be strongly opposed to this (many creators have a negative relationship with money) but I promise that your success (no matter how you define it) relies on you realizing this. https://t.co/0Hgo1rEint

@HollyShannon_ @buymeacoffee @podcastingsucks @retoldpodcast I'm was a poor kid from a poor neighborhood who grew up poor... I think my listeners are, somehow, like me in that regard. I think I resonate with the @podcastingsucks for this reason, and I think they're keen to support me financially because that resonance has built trust.

@HollyShannon_ @buymeacoffee @podcastingsucks @retoldpodcast And I suspect that my no bullshit approach, which is curt and direct, attracts the kind of people to whom the notion of paying your neighbor in beer for their help because you're trying to save money or can't afford a mechanic, resonates strongly.

@HollyShannon_ @buymeacoffee @podcastingsucks @retoldpodcast Supporting the show is elective, but I couch the call to support in "everyman" language - which is natural for me to do because I *am* an everyman; so it comes off as it truly is: genuine. I compare supporting the show to buying a 12-pack for your neighbor when they fix your car

@HollyShannon_ @buymeacoffee I don't think @podcastingsucks provides more value than @retoldpodcast, but I think the value it provides is easier to see as financially valuable and thus quicker (and easier) to monetize. I also think it matters the language I couch the CTA in (which you've heard on the show).

@HollyShannon_ @buymeacoffee Top level: I think people are more likely to assign a dollar value to information they need (even when its free) than they are to assign a dollar value to the experience of being entertained. I have another podcast, about as old, far fewer episodes, same size-ish, $0.00.

@HollyShannon_ No it's @buymeacoffee and each "coffee" is, instead, a beer and costs $5.

There's a psychology at play here that I think is important and that I want to write about - I think there's a reason I'm having this much financial success this early (only 40 eps are public, so $9.75/ep)

I kind of liked that. I liked that it was a semi-secured method of building credit and so relatively low risk loan on everyone’s part. So I applied and got it. If your small business could benefit from a small loan to build your business credit, I would look into this 😊

But I thought “how strange stripe would offer this to a business so young and without a proven, or even strongly projected annual revenue.” Then I looked at the terms. “20% of every payment goes towards repayment. $250 a month is the minimum.” So if I bill, I’m servicing the debt

Stripe reached out and said that since my young business was performing strongly (which isn’t big money, it’s just a decent living) it was eligible for a $2000 loan. I don’t usually do loans because, well, I don’t like owing people money. I especially don’t like owing banks money

🧵 Thread for my #IndiePodcast #PodNation and #PodernFamily fams. It's about @GoodpodsHQ's ranking process and a link to the 13-minute episode discussing it further can be found in the last tweet of the thread. Thanks! https://t.co/aL8UAJYkz2
The full episode discussing this @GoodpodsHQ rankings can be found at https://t.co/CdkPMuvSQl - or (mostly) wherever you listen to your podcasts... which is hopefully on Goodpods.

And, again, the way they're addressing discovery is clever, and their app is getting better by the day so... here's the takeaway:

1. Yes, the rankings are isolated from "real" global rankings

2. That doesn't matter

3. Use @GoodpodsHQ and build some community there. https://t.co/pJve9v4Ggf

And you SHOULD be using @GoodpodsHQ because it gives you a much better chance of being found organically than any other platform can give you (I would say including @Podchaser). Of course as the platform grows, competition will increase, but at least not mainstream competition.

I was hesitant to answer this question from Heather because some people may think "Oh well, I guess that means @GoodpodsHQ is make believe" but it's NOT. It's how we rank when we remove the behemoths from the charts... and we indies NEED that; and SHOULD have it.

Make the default position of that slider "on", or somehow make it difficult for non-indies to be explored/discovered on the app. Maybe even a choice at sign up that asks "What do you want to use the app for most? Mainstream stuff or hidden gems?" then adjusting the ux accordingly

However, the moment mainstream users start picking up this app, we're going to lose this - or we WOULD if @GoodpodsHQ hadn't been clever enough to include an "Indie Only" toggle (which you can see is off in the top right corner).  I would press them to go a step further and...

What @goodpods has done, so far, is create an ecosystem of users that seem to have significantly less interest in listening to mainstream podcasts. They've also found a clever way around podcasting's discovery issues by putting what your friends are listening to in your timeline.

More context from the images. My podcast *does not even rank* in the United States. And do you really think I would be outcompeting @NPR's "Up First" Or @crookedmedia's "What A Day"? Of course not. But that's the great thing about @GoodpodsHQ... hold on, I'll say more... https://t.co/oKFwXK6YFJ

This is why I’m always hammering on about setting expectations and meeting them as frequently and reliably as possible.

But then they land on a page with shitty design, less compelling artwork, and a completely (by comparison) subpar experience. They’ll never click play because the disparity in experience will make them feel hoodwinked. They’ll leave.

Here’s an example… your display ad used great copy, and features compelling and visually engaging creative. This results in a high CTR and low CPC, and you’re pumped about that! 20 clicks for $1!? Yes please!

Tip:

The quality of your marketing assets shouldn’t overpromise on your podcast. If you’re going to design a kick as esthetic, and you’re going to get a top tier bad ass VO intro with great music, you can’t let that effort dump people into a webcam recorded zoom podcast.

@indiedropin Algorithmic discovery would change the game. Imagine if @spotifypodcasts said “For $0 a month we’ll put your podcast in front of new listeners whom we’ve identified as being your demographic.” How huge would that be? Recurring, regular, dependable growth every month.

I need breakfast. https://t.co/S2H2fsCs25
@MoralCombatPod But also… let me work so you don’t have to be starving, alright? 😉
@indiedropin See, now it’s a sport or a contest. It didn’t used to be that way.
@realnealveglio @ChartableDotCom I’ve DM’d you on that subject. I’ve got breakfast to get to. Take care for now.

@realnealveglio @ChartableDotCom They do work… there’s a reason my clients don’t leave… growth has a lot to do with it, cause it surely isn’t my rosey disposition. I know why you’re saying that, and I’ll accept that jab because it’s going to set me up later. Please don’t delete this tweet 😉
@indiedropin 😂

@realnealveglio @ChartableDotCom I must feel it’s far too much and they need help. They need easy ways to market, a closed system can give them that. Decentralized won’t die, but it’s for the most pro among us, not for the indie who is just an artist.

@realnealveglio It’s reasonable to expect them to learn some marketing skills, but to the degree that they could teach on the subject? I’m spending $300/mo on adspend and $100/mo on @ChartableDotCom… I’ve also been a marketing director in my past. should they be expected to do and be the same?

@realnealveglio And regardless whether we do or don’t, shouldn’t we be building ways for creators to focus more on creation than on all the rest? Isn’t that going to bring us the greatest number of voices? Isn’t that what’s best? That’s what I think anyway.

@realnealveglio And they fade because they can’t get it… and they can’t get it because they aren’t marketers (mostly it is a marketing problem) and so the reality today is that if you don’t have marketing savvy, you can’t make it. Is it fair that we expect all voices to have this skill set?

@realnealveglio I don’t feel that’s anyones idea I’d success, not if they’ve truly thought about it. People want money, or impact, or reach, at least one of those and so no one can feel content with 25 engaged listeners for the duration of their podcasting career because 25 doesn’t equal either.
@realnealveglio @AlbanBrooke I may not have. Alban? What’s the word?

@realnealveglio I just don’t feel that’s a very creator-centric view, I think that’s a very “work with the best and don’t worry about them til they’re the best” view. I does need a better shot to be seen in order to be successful, and we should be building based on that.

@realnealveglio And Apple Podcasts itself is only where it is because it was the only mass produced device that picked up on podcasting early on. So they’re the #1 platform in the US, and that’s something, but they’re not innovators in the podcasting space.

@realnealveglio That being the case is a side effect less of innovation and more of Apple’s devices being popular and most people not venturing out of native to find better players. Their player is terrible.

@realnealveglio And those with huge audiences are practically no one… and certainly aren’t “indie” … the top 200 lists are almost exclusively npr, nyt, wondery, etc. when people say they listen to podcasts, it’s extremely likely they’re talking about those top 200 types, not indies.

@realnealveglio Well yes that’s certainly not untrue. But podcasters didn’t used to need to be great marketers and networkers and this and that, they used to just need to create great content. The increased noise mean less opportunity for the non-elite creators. Is that what we want?

@realnealveglio It’s a head-in-the-sand scenario. They all could have seen the writing in the wall, pivoted, got there first, and we’d have good people creating the future of the podcasting landscape instead of corporate profit-driven interests. And now, I feel strongly, it’s too late.

@realnealveglio Spotify, has done more for podcasters in the last 2-years than has been done in the last 15. And eventually the bulk of creators will start in that platform… it’s inevitable and for personal emotional reasons people want to deny it rather than@accept it and shape it to be better

@realnealveglio And that existing leadership has fought this move because they couldn’t provide such a landscape and needed their businesses to stay relevant or because they think centralization hurts free speech. In either case, and in the end, those that didn’t dawdle have gained the advantage
@realnealveglio Example: algorithmic driven discovey, pixel driven advertising and marketing, and all inclusive community building.

@realnealveglio My point is that building an audience in a decentralized landscape is not only increasingly difficult, but increasingly borders on being impossible, and that moving to centralized would make it easier and more profitable, as a centralized landscape enables tech that de-cent can’t

Helping people see this is why I spend hundreds of dollars a month testing ads on platforms like @spotifyads and Facebook for podcasters. This is a piece you need an I'm hellbent on helping podcasters understand that.

This is why marketers are always going on about the importance niches.

The more niche the target, the easier it is to target it. The less money you'll spend targeting it. The more relevant you'll be to the target. The better results you'll get.

And you might think "But eventually everyone will pay and the same problem will arise, right?"

Kind of. But not really. 

If everyone did paid social, not all of them would do it well and not all of them would target the same niche.

Think about it like this:

Population 1 : everyone who tweets

Population 2 : everyone who tweets and is willing to spend money to make sure people see their tweets

If you can afford to be in pool 2 and your content isn't trashy spammy marketing, who do you think wins?

@DrunkTheory Let's do it. 

But first... pub? https://t.co/BjN3EhAn0a

And to be clear, my #PodNation and #IndiePodcast fams, the reason you run paid ads is because you need to be seen doing the work, and organic will not allow many people to see that. You need paid social to break through to your niche.

Fuck all other marketing advice you've heard, the secret to growth on any platform - Twitter, podcast, TikTok, doesn't matter - is:

Run paid ads
Be active
Be real
Be useful

Gaming algorithms might give you an edge, but nothing works like putting in the work #PodNation https://t.co/clbBJIgBpB

So, I think, in this specific situation, all this podcaster needs to do is get permission from the artist who created the cover of the cover, and that should be sufficient.

Am I wrong?

My thought is that if they use the cover of the cover without permission, the cover-cover artist could say "Hey! I didn't say you could use that!" because it's their cover... but they could not charge a fee to use it because if they did, they'd need to pay Katy Perry a royalty...

The cover of the aforementioned cover, doesn't sell their cover either, though if the did I imagine they'd still be paying the original artist the royalty and not the original cover artist (confused yet?). So, back to my listener:

You still need to pay the original artist a royalty *if* you sell the song. The first person to cover this song, in this situation, does not sell their cover, instead, they allow people to download it for free. I imagine because they don't care to make money OR pay royalties...

This individual wants to use a segment of a cover of a cover of a Katy Perry song in their podcast outro. My understanding of covers, if you're an artist *creating* one, is that you are allowed to do so without permission thanks to compulsory licensing, but...

I have a listener who has come to me with some music licensing questions. This is a thread and I'd really like it if some music brains (maybe @Artlist_io @PodcastMusic_SA etc) could weigh in on this. Maybe even @gfiremark. Here we go...

@plasticAudio In other words I don’t think it’s fair to elevate an audio editing tool to the level of a workstation. If not for any other reason than setting fair expectations based on what we, as professionals, expect a DAW to be capable of.
